quiz.title: Physics 11: Unit 3 Quiz 6
quiz.subtitle: Levers – Mechanical Advantage, Velocity Ratio, and Efficiency
quiz.subject: Physics 11

questions.question: A first-class lever has the fulcrum 0.3 m from a 400 N load and 0.9 m from the effort. What is the ideal mechanical advantage?
questions.explanation: Ideal MA = Effort arm length / Load arm length = 0.9 m / 0.3 m = 3.0

questions.question: A lever lifts a 400 N load 0.1 m while the effort moves 0.35 m. If the effort required is 114.3 N, what is the actual mechanical advantage?
questions.explanation: Actual MA = Load / Effort = 400 N / 114.3 N ≈ 2.29

questions.question: A lever system has an ideal MA of 3.0 but an actual MA of 2.29. What is its efficiency (as a percentage)?
A second-class lever has the load 0.4 m from the fulcrum and effort 1.2 m from the fulcrum. What is the velocity ratio?
questions.explanation: VR = Effort arm / Load arm = 1.2 m / 0.4 m = 3.0

questions.question: A lever system has a velocity ratio of 4 and an efficiency of 80%. What actual mechanical advantage does it provide?
A worker applies 150 N of effort to lift a 450 N crate using a lever. What is the actual mechanical advantage?
questions.explanation: Actual MA = Load / Effort = 450 N / 150 N = 3.0

questions.question: A lever requires the effort to move 0.6 m to lift the load 0.15 m. What is the velocity ratio?
questions.explanation: VR = Distance effort moves / Distance load moves = 0.6 m / 0.15 m = 4.0

questions.question: A lever system has an actual MA of 3 and a VR of 4. What is its efficiency?
A third-class lever has an effort arm of 0.25 m and a load arm of 0.75 m. What is its ideal mechanical advantage?
questions.explanation: Ideal MA = Effort arm / Load arm = 0.25 m / 0.75 m = 1/3 ≈ 0.33

questions.question: A lever system is 60% efficient and has a velocity ratio of 5. How much effort is needed to lift a 300 N load?
questions.explanation: MA = Efficiency × VR = 0.60 × 5 = 3.0. Effort = Load / MA = 300 N / 3 = 100 N

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You’ve mastered lever MA, VR, and efficiency concepts.
scoreMessages.70: Very good! Solid understanding; review the efficiency formula (MA/VR)×100%.
scoreMessages.50: Fair. Practice distinguishing between actual MA, ideal MA, and VR.
scoreMessages.0: Review lever classes, MA = Load/Effort, VR = Effort arm/Load arm.
